VOL. XXV. No. 3
DAILY

BULLETIN MAKES
APPEARANCE

To Contain All Daily Announcements.
Is Edited by News-Letter — Announcements to Be In by 1
P. M. of Preceding Day.

Last Monday there appeared at
Hopkins the first issue .of the
Daily Bulletin for 1920-21. This
sheet, which contains each morning announcements for the day,
will fill a long-felt want. It has
always been very difficult to get
the announcements of the meetings and plans of the various
activities, the calls for class meetings and all matters of general
interest before the students for
whom they are intended. The bulletin boards are always so crowded
that ` notices are overlooked, or,
oftener still, the students pass by
the boards without attempting to
ferret out the notice in which they
are interested. The Bulletin. will
enable every man to know everything that is going on every day.
Some inkling of the Usefulness
of the Bulletin may be gotten by
recalling the short-lived and rather
crude "Bulletin" which the Y. M.
C. A. published for a brief period
last year. This year the NEWSLETTER has undertaken the work,
and is going to turn out a more
finished sheet. There will be two
inches of advertisements, which
will help to pay the costs of printing, which will be of the printfaced multigraphing type. Later
in the year, if the circumstances
warrant it, an editorial and similar features will be published every
day.
Al those having any announcemeuts to be put in the Bulletin
can!co-operate by turning them in
at the postoffice before one o'clock
the day previous to the one when
they are to appear.

BALTIMORE, MD., OCTOBER 19, 1920

PRICE 10 CENTS

UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA DOWNS
VARSITY 14-0

DORMITORY PLEDGES TO
BE COLLECTED.

Game Dull and Monotonous, with Few Thrills
Largest Crowd Ever Before Seen at Homewood
—Swarthmore Booked for Saturday

The great success which the
campaign for funds for the Johns
Hopkins dormitories, and the nearness of the time for their erection,
has led the committee to continue
more earnestly their efforts to
raise the amount. Mr, Graham
Boyce, the Treasurer of the University, has been given authority by
Mr. Radcliffe's committee to send
out bills for the first instalment
of the pledges which were due last
February. For some reason or
other this has been delayed until
the present time. Mr. Boyce is
hoping to reach everyone who
pledged, and expects that the
whole of the instalment will be
paid within a week after the bills
lire sent out. The next instalment
will be asked for in February,
1921.
The pledge permits the donor to
give in five instalments—one-fifth
of the total amount each year, or
he may pay the entire sum at once.
It is hoped that most men will pay
the whole now so that the Dormitory Fund Committee can have
more money on hand. All checks
from undergraduates are to be
made payable to the University,
and left at the Treasurer's office.
Alumni will pay their instalments
to their regular class committee
leaders or forward their checks to
13 W. Saratoga St. Dormitories
are now the most unique need of
the University, and their erection
in the near future is a necessity.
It is hoped that all those who
failed to pledge us last year will
do so this year,

The Johns Hopkins football team was doteated last Saturday by
the University of Virginia, 14 to 0. Except at a few very rare moments, when flashes of real football were shown, the game was dull
and monotonous, with a great variety of penalties, delays, fumbles,
punts and incomplete forward passes. A blazing sun made fast,
snappy football impossible, while the inability of the Virginia team to
hold on to the ball, and of the Hopkins men to gain ground consistently, still further slowed up the game. The stage was all set for a
great contest.; a fine crowd packed its way into the stands, the Hopkins rooters were out in full force with their band, and across the way
the Virginia supporters made up for lack of numbers by volume of
sound. They saw Hopkins fight doggedly to throw back the frequently
successful attacks of the Southerners and hold their opponents for
four downs only a few feet from the goal; they saw some pretty running by Rinehart and Zundel, and the completion of a long forward
pass by each side. But, on the whole, the game was not much more
than an exhibition of splendid punting by Calkins and Rinehart.
With the exception of the first quarter, Virginia's goal line was
never seriously in danger. The Black and Blue forwards could do little
with their heavier opponents,'while the backs, slow in starting, were
frequently thrown for a loss. Throughout the game the Southerners
were clearly superior, although they were often unable to gain and
were forced to add another to the long string of punts. 'Much of the
effectiveness of their attack was lost in the numerous penalties they
incurred and the fumbles they committed, which probably gained more
ground for the Black and Blue team than the plunges of their backs.
Calkins opened the hostilities
by kicking off to Zundel, who was
downed by Bill Wood after a short
run. Virginia then begania niarch
down the field, which came to a
sudden end when Swartzbaugh
fell on tt. fumble. After two unsuccessful attempts to pierce the Virginia line Calkins kicked. On the
next play Rinehart again fumbled
and Bill Wood recovered, but to
no avail, for the Southerners held
for downs on their own 15-yard
line. From then on the play seesawed up and down the field, with
neither team able to do much on
the offensive until a fumble placed
the Virginians within striking distance of the Hopkins goal. A desperate defense on the part of the
Black and Blue held the ball for
four downs a few inches from the
line, but an off-side play made it
first down, and Zundel went over
for a touchdown, Hall kicking
goal. The rest of the half was a
succession of kicks, with neither
side making an apparent gain.

Virginia kicked off for the second half; Hopkins could not gain
and returned the ball. The rest
of the third quarter was a long
succession of kicks, with one long
dash by Jones in between. Virginia began to use forward passes,
but the fine work of the Hopkins
backfield made them useless; only
one was completed, while Calkins
intercepted another.
The last quarter saw the final
lowering of the hopes of the Johns
Hopkins stands. The Southerners
suddenly gave up the kicking game
and began a march down the field.
A long forward pass for 25 yards
placed the ball 10 yards from the
goal; in three more downs it had
been shoved over for the final
score of the day. From then on
the only feature of the game was
the completion of a long forward
pass, Calkins to Knecht.
With the exception of the fine
defensive play of Bill Wood and
Elmer Jones, and the long spirals

Men will look better
this season
This season's style is quite different; and many college men
will be glad, because it is more
comfortable and easy-looking
than the soldier-like models of
past seasons.
The new coats have a free
swing from the shoulders —
the waist line is lower and not
shaped in—the vent is shorter
and behaves better.
And remember there is art

in the cut of a full coat. It
must hang 1.:ght when you sit
or stand—when it's buttoned
or unbuttoned— when your
arms are up or down.
Art in design is what has
made the Style reputation of
Society Brand Clothes. And
all-wool fabrics along with.
fine hand-tailoring hold these
clothes to the lines of the
design.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS. NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 19 ,1920
DR. H. A. KELLY GIVES RECEPTION TO FOREIGN
STUDENTS.
Addresses Made by Dr. Kelly, Dr.
Hitti and Mr. Gacitua.

Cosmopolitan Club To Be Organized.

the foreign students of the
Johns Hopkins University were
entertained last Friday night by
Dr. Howard A. Kelly, Professor
Emeritus of Gynecology in the
University, at his home, 1406 Eutaw Place. It has been the annual
custom of Dr. Kelly for many
years to have these• men in his
home at least once a year, and the
privilege of intimately meeting
such an international figure is
always eagerly received and appreciated.
All

Addresses were made by Dr.
Kelly, Dr. Philip Hitti of Syria
and Mr. Oscar Gacitua of Chile.
Dr. Hitti and Mr. Gacitua are representatives of the Committee on
Friendly Relations Among Foreign Students, and have had wide
experience in their work with foreign students in their club organizations throughout the whole of
the United States.
Those present were unanimously
of the opinion that such a large
and influential university as Johns
Hopkins should have a Cosmopolitan Club. Dr. Hitti explained
that the basis for such a club was
(1) the unity of the human race,
regardless of color, creed and culture; (2) the individuality within
this unity, which must be preserved and expressed; and (3) the
contributions of each nationality
brought into focus for common international good. After a thorough
discussion of the opportunities
and difficulties of the Club, a committee was appointed to draw up
a constitution, to report for adoption in the near future. The committee appointed was Dr. H. J.
Pelc, Czecho-Slovakia, from the
School of Hygiene; Mr. P. C.
Hsieh, China, from the Graduate
School; Mr. N. Inouye, Japan,
from the Engineering School; Mr.
C. C. Hansen Peru from the Medical School;
S. H. Linn, China,
from the Academic Department,
and Mr. E. Pierce Hayes, General
Secretary, University Y. M. C. A.
The Cosmopolitan Club in other
large cities has become quite a
municipal pride, and the men are
frequently entertained by the
Chamber of Commerce, Rotary
and Kiwanis clubs, these organizations seeing the possible benefits
from international good will, such
as the Club will aim to create.
The next meeting of the Club
will be at the Central Y. M. C. A.,
Cathedral and Franklin streets,
October 22, at 6.30 &clock, when
the fifty to sixty foreign men and
women at Johns Hopkins will join
hands around the common dinner
table with a few of their American
friends.

To the Editor of the Mail Bag:
Dear Sir—I have read with
great interest and approval the
editorial in the October 12 issue
of the NEWS-LETTER Concerning
student elections. An unhappy
example of the present system was
furnished by the election of officers
in the Sophomore Class this year.
The class meeting was announced
two days before the election, by
the pinning of small sheets of
paper on the bulletin boards, which
contained, among others, these
words:"Election of Officers." Two
days later the class met in the
Mechanical Engineering Building,
and, with little premeditation,
proceeded to elect the officers to
govern it this year.
First, the nominations for the
two "Hullabaloo" representatives
were received, and these men, with
little opposition, were elected by
a standing vote. Next, nominations were held for the Presidency.
Four. names, I think, were mentioned, and immediately the balloting, if a standing vote can be
called such, was held. The men
in the class, before that time, did
not know from which men they
were going to choose; they had had
no time to consider candidates;
they had very little time to determine for whom to vote. In this
election the successful condidate
won by a clear majority.
In the case of the election of
vice-president there was a difference. On the first vote, no nominee had a majority. Immediately,
some members of the class held
that a plurality was all that was
necessary. The constitution was
called for, but its location could
not be determined. Several methods of solving the difficulty were
suggested, but none was accepted.
The meeting passed into a disorderly gathering. Several members, emulating, I suppose, that
"wilful handful of men" in the
Senate, attempted to filibuster so
that they could elect, by means
no one knew, their candidates.
Finally the meeting adjourned un-

NEW LECTURE COURSES

of three new courses in the night
school of the University. As in
other night classes, no special academic training is required for admission to the courses, but applicants must satisfy the instructors

work, and in the railway accounting course must have a knowledge
of the fundamentals of bookkeeping. The fee is NO for each
course.

"The Johns Hopkins University
announces the inauguration of a
course of lectures to be known as
The Gilman Memorial Lectures on
Geography. These lectures are
made possible through the generosity of the friends of Daniel Colt
Gilman, first president of the
Johns Hopkins University. Dr.
Gilman began his teaching career
at Yale (1863-1872) as professor
of physical and political geography, and was a member of the
United States Commission on the
Boundary Line Between Venezuela and British Guiana in
1896-97."
"The first series of lectures will
be given by Major Lawrence Martin of the General Staff Corps,
United States Army, who, as the
chief of the Geographic Section,
Military Intelligence, attached to
the American Commission to Negotiate Peace, had unusual opportunities for studying at first hand
the geographic factors affecting
trade in the reorganized States of
Europe and Asia Minor."
Railway Accounting.

The Johns Hopkins University
offers a course of approximately
25 lectures on railway accounting, to be given by Mr. Frank A.
• Deverell, assistant comptroller of
the Baltimore & Ohio Railroad Co.
The purpose of the course is to
enable those now engaged in the
railroad business and others contemplating entering railroad service or the service of the Interstate
Commerce Commission to acquire
a general knowledge of the principles and practices of railway
accounting.
Scope of Course.
Industrial Relations.

The Johns Hopkins University
offers a course of approximately
25 lectures on industrial relations,
to be given by Dr. Borii Emmet,.
labor manager of Henry Sonneborn & Co.
The course will aim to cover
in a practical way the principal
phases of modern employment
management and the latest trends
in industrial relations.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 19, 1921)
CROSS COUNTRY
Last Wednesday, the first workout of the Cross Country squad
took place under the directiOn of
Coach Joe England, who expressed
pleasure over the appearance of
the material. The prospects for a
good team this year are rather
promising, for dmong the older
men taking part in practice were
Mullikin (captain), Norwood, Hazeltine, Heiner, Cannon and Buchner, all of last year's squad.
Among the newcomers, Jefferson,
who ran for the Penn Freshmen
last year, and Martin, from Cumberland High, showed to advantage. Somerville and Holzopple,
who, although upper classmen,
were not out last year, are numbered in this year's candidates.
Although quite a number of men
are trying for the team, more are
needed if the Cross Country is to
uphold the standards of the other
Hopkins teams. Coach Joe England will be glad to see any new
men who are anxious to try out
for the squad.
With the Cross Country squad,
several general track men are also
practicing. The opportunity for
getting into good condition for
spring track is thus available, and
foresighted track men will take
advantage of it by donning their
togs every Wednesday and going
through a general work-out.

7

The Medical Standard Book Co.

in the "Barn."

Prospects Bright for Successful Season.
Interesting Schedule Planned for
Next Meeting.

The first meeting of the Social
Science Club, which was held
Friday, October 8, forecasts a successful, as well as a prosperous
year. In addition to the improvement in financial status, due to the
large number of new members,
marked enthusiasm was shown by
those who attended.
Three assistant secretaries were
elected in order to provide more
adequate methods for advertising
the meetings and public lectures.
Messrs. E. Smith, 'Junior • H. 0.
West,Sophomore, and W.14.Bruck,
Freshman, who were elected to fill
these positions, have always taken
an active interest in the Club.
A membership drive has been
planned, and a Membership Committee composed of one representative'
from each class, was appointed.
At the next meeting, to be held
on Friday, October 22, Mr. West
will read a paper on "The Platform of the Democratic Party,"
and Mr. Louis Kelley will discourse on "The Republican Platform." West is as ardent a
-Democrat" as Kelley is a "Republican," and undoubtedly those
in attendance will gain much
valuable information as to the
aims of both parties.
A discussion of the relative
merits of the two party platforms
will follow, and those versed in
the literature of the Presidential
campaign will be afforded an opportunity to display their knowledge.
A large attendance is hoped for.

always been very difficult to get
the announcements of the meetings and plans of the various
activities, the calls for class meetings and all matters of general
interest before the students for
whom they are intended. The bulletin boards are always so crowded
that ` notices are overlooked, or,
oftener still, the students pass by
the boards without attempting to
ferret out the notice in which they
are interested. The Bulletin. will
enable every man to know everything that is going on every day.
Some inkling of the Usefulness
of the Bulletin may be gotten by
recalling the short-lived and rather
crude "Bulletin" which the Y. M.
C. A. published for a brief period
last year. This year the NEWSLETTER has undertaken the work,

inches of advertisements, which

UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA DOWNS
VARSITY 14-0

DORMITORY PLEDGES TO
BE COLLECTED.

Game Dull and Monotonous, with Few Thrills
Largest Crowd Ever Before Seen at Homewood
—Swarthmore Booked for Saturday

The great success which the
campaign for funds for the Johns
Hopkins dormitories, and the nearness of the time for their erection,
has led the committee to continue
more earnestly their efforts to
raise the amount. Mr, Graham
Boyce, the Treasurer of the University, has been given authority by
Mr. Radcliffe's committee to send
out bills for the first instalment
of the pledges which were due last
February. For some reason or
other this has been delayed until
the present time. Mr. Boyce is
hoping to reach everyone who
pledged, and expects that the
whole of the instalment will be
paid within a week after the bills
lire sent out. The next instalment
will be asked for in February,
1921.
The pledge permits the donor to
give in five instalments—one-fifth
of the total amount each year, or
he may pay the entire sum at once.
It is hoped that most men will pay
the whole now so that the Dormitory Fund Committee can have
more money on hand. All checks
from undergraduates are to be
made payable to the University,
and left at the Treasurer's office.
Alumni will pay their instalments
to their regular class committee
leaders or forward their checks to
13 W. Saratoga St. Dormitories
are now the most unique need of
the University, and their erection
in the near future is a necessity.
It is hoped that all those who
failed to pledge us last year will
do so this year,

The Johns Hopkins football team was doteated last Saturday by
the University of Virginia, 14 to 0. Except at a few very rare moments, when flashes of real football were shown, the game was dull
and monotonous, with a great variety of penalties, delays, fumbles,
punts and incomplete forward passes. A blazing sun made fast,
snappy football impossible, while the inability of the Virginia team to
hold on to the ball, and of the Hopkins men to gain ground consistently, still further slowed up the game. The stage was all set for a
great contest.; a fine crowd packed its way into the stands, the Hopkins rooters were out in full force with their band, and across the way
the Virginia supporters made up for lack of numbers by volume of
sound. They saw Hopkins fight doggedly to throw back the frequently
successful attacks of the Southerners and hold their opponents for
four downs only a few feet from the goal; they saw some pretty running by Rinehart and Zundel, and the completion of a long forward
pass by each side. But, on the whole, the game was not much more
than an exhibition of splendid punting by Calkins and Rinehart.
With the exception of the first quarter, Virginia's goal line was
never seriously in danger. The Black and Blue forwards could do little
with their heavier opponents,'while the backs, slow in starting, were
frequently thrown for a loss. Throughout the game the Southerners
were clearly superior, although they were often unable to gain and
were forced to add another to the long string of punts. 'Much of the
effectiveness of their attack was lost in the numerous penalties they
incurred and the fumbles they committed, which probably gained more
ground for the Black and Blue team than the plunges of their backs.
Calkins opened the hostilities
by kicking off to Zundel, who was
downed by Bill Wood after a short
run. Virginia then begania niarch
down the field, which came to a
sudden end when Swartzbaugh
fell on tt. fumble. After two unsuccessful attempts to pierce the Virginia line Calkins kicked. On the
next play Rinehart again fumbled
and Bill Wood recovered, but to
no avail, for the Southerners held
for downs on their own 15-yard
line. From then on the play seesawed up and down the field, with
neither team able to do much on
the offensive until a fumble placed
the Virginians within striking distance of the Hopkins goal. A desperate defense on the part of the
Black and Blue held the ball for
four downs a few inches from the
line, but an off-side play made it
first down, and Zundel went over
for a touchdown, Hall kicking
goal. The rest of the half was a
succession of kicks, with neither
side making an apparent gain.

Virginia kicked off for the second half; Hopkins could not gain
and returned the ball. The rest
of the third quarter was a long
succession of kicks, with one long
dash by Jones in between. Virginia began to use forward passes,
but the fine work of the Hopkins
backfield made them useless; only
one was completed, while Calkins
intercepted another.
The last quarter saw the final
lowering of the hopes of the Johns
Hopkins stands. The Southerners
suddenly gave up the kicking game
and began a march down the field.
A long forward pass for 25 yards
placed the ball 10 yards from the
goal; in three more downs it had
been shoved over for the final
score of the day. From then on
the only feature of the game was
the completion of a long forward
pass, Calkins to Knecht.

defensive play of Bill Wood and

THE JOHNS HOPKINS. NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 19 ,1920
DR. H. A. KELLY GIVES RECEPTION TO FOREIGN
STUDENTS.
Addresses Made by Dr. Kelly, Dr.
Hitti and Mr. Gacitua.

Cosmopolitan Club To Be Organized.

the foreign students of the
Johns Hopkins University were
entertained last Friday night by
Dr. Howard A. Kelly, Professor
Emeritus of Gynecology in the
University, at his home, 1406 Eutaw Place. It has been the annual
custom of Dr. Kelly for many
years to have these• men in his
home at least once a year, and the
privilege of intimately meeting
such an international figure is
always eagerly received and appreciated.
All

Addresses were made by Dr.
Kelly, Dr. Philip Hitti of Syria
and Mr. Oscar Gacitua of Chile.
Dr. Hitti and Mr. Gacitua are representatives of the Committee on
Friendly Relations Among Foreign Students, and have had wide
experience in their work with foreign students in their club organizations throughout the whole of
the United States.
Those present were unanimously
of the opinion that such a large
and influential university as Johns
Hopkins should have a Cosmopolitan Club. Dr. Hitti explained
that the basis for such a club was
(1) the unity of the human race,
regardless of color, creed and culture; (2) the individuality within
this unity, which must be preserved and expressed; and (3) the
contributions of each nationality
brought into focus for common international good. After a thorough
discussion of the opportunities
and difficulties of the Club, a committee was appointed to draw up
a constitution, to report for adoption in the near future. The committee appointed was Dr. H. J.
Pelc, Czecho-Slovakia, from the
School of Hygiene; Mr. P. C.
Hsieh, China, from the Graduate
School; Mr. N. Inouye, Japan,
from the Engineering School; Mr.
C. C. Hansen Peru from the Medical School;
S. H. Linn, China,
from the Academic Department,
and Mr. E. Pierce Hayes, General
Secretary, University Y. M. C. A.
The Cosmopolitan Club in other
large cities has become quite a
municipal pride, and the men are
frequently entertained by the
Chamber of Commerce, Rotary
and Kiwanis clubs, these organizations seeing the possible benefits
from international good will, such
as the Club will aim to create.
The next meeting of the Club
will be at the Central Y. M. C. A.,
Cathedral and Franklin streets,
October 22, at 6.30 &clock, when
the fifty to sixty foreign men and
women at Johns Hopkins will join
hands around the common dinner
table with a few of their American

To the Editor of the Mail Bag:
Dear Sir—I have read with
great interest and approval the
editorial in the October 12 issue
of the NEWS-LETTER Concerning
student elections. An unhappy
example of the present system was
furnished by the election of officers
in the Sophomore Class this year.
The class meeting was announced
two days before the election, by
the pinning of small sheets of
paper on the bulletin boards, which
contained, among others, these
words:"Election of Officers." Two
days later the class met in the
Mechanical Engineering Building,
and, with little premeditation,
proceeded to elect the officers to
govern it this year.
First, the nominations for the
two "Hullabaloo" representatives
were received, and these men, with
little opposition, were elected by
a standing vote. Next, nominations were held for the Presidency.
Four. names, I think, were mentioned, and immediately the balloting, if a standing vote can be
called such, was held. The men
in the class, before that time, did
not know from which men they
were going to choose; they had had
no time to consider candidates;
they had very little time to determine for whom to vote. In this
election the successful condidate
won by a clear majority.
In the case of the election of
vice-president there was a difference. On the first vote, no nominee had a majority. Immediately,
some members of the class held
that a plurality was all that was
necessary. The constitution was
called for, but its location could
not be determined. Several methods of solving the difficulty were
suggested, but none was accepted.
The meeting passed into a disorderly gathering. Several members, emulating, I suppose, that
"wilful handful of men" in the
Senate, attempted to filibuster so
that they could elect, by means
no one knew, their candidates.
Finally the meeting adjourned un-

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 19, 1920
NEW LECTURE COURSES
ANNOUNCED
Announcement has been made
of three new courses in the night
school of the University. As in
other night classes, no special academic training is required for admission to the courses, but applicants must satisfy the instructors
of their ability to profit from the
work, and in the railway accounting course must have a knowledge
of the fundamentals of bookkeeping. The fee is NO for each
course.

"The Johns Hopkins University
announces the inauguration of a
course of lectures to be known as
The Gilman Memorial Lectures on
Geography. These lectures are
made possible through the generosity of the friends of Daniel Colt
Gilman, first president of the
Johns Hopkins University. Dr.
Gilman began his teaching career
at Yale (1863-1872) as professor
of physical and political geography, and was a member of the
United States Commission on the
Boundary Line Between Venezuela and British Guiana in
1896-97."
"The first series of lectures will
be given by Major Lawrence Martin of the General Staff Corps,
United States Army, who, as the
chief of the Geographic Section,
Military Intelligence, attached to
the American Commission to Negotiate Peace, had unusual opportunities for studying at first hand
the geographic factors affecting
trade in the reorganized States of
Europe and Asia Minor."
Railway Accounting.

The Johns Hopkins University
offers a course of approximately
25 lectures on railway accounting, to be given by Mr. Frank A.
• Deverell, assistant comptroller of
the Baltimore & Ohio Railroad Co.
The purpose of the course is to
enable those now engaged in the
railroad business and others contemplating entering railroad service or the service of the Interstate
Commerce Commission to acquire
a general knowledge of the principles and practices of railway
accounting.
Scope of Course.
Industrial Relations.

The Johns Hopkins University
offers a course of approximately
25 lectures on industrial relations,
to be given by Dr. Borii Emmet,.
labor manager of Henry Sonneborn & Co.
The course will aim to cover
in a practical way the principal
phases of modern employment
management and the latest trends
in industrial relations.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 19, 1921)
CROSS COUNTRY
Last Wednesday, the first workout of the Cross Country squad
took place under the directiOn of
Coach Joe England, who expressed
pleasure over the appearance of
the material. The prospects for a
good team this year are rather
promising, for dmong the older
men taking part in practice were
Mullikin (captain), Norwood, Hazeltine, Heiner, Cannon and Buchner, all of last year's squad.
Among the newcomers, Jefferson,
who ran for the Penn Freshmen
last year, and Martin, from Cumberland High, showed to advantage. Somerville and Holzopple,
who, although upper classmen,
were not out last year, are numbered in this year's candidates.
Although quite a number of men
are trying for the team, more are
needed if the Cross Country is to
uphold the standards of the other
Hopkins teams. Coach Joe England will be glad to see any new
men who are anxious to try out
for the squad.
With the Cross Country squad,
several general track men are also
practicing. The opportunity for
getting into good condition for
spring track is thus available, and
foresighted track men will take
advantage of it by donning their
togs every Wednesday and going
through a general work-out.

in the "Barn."

Prospects Bright for Successful Season.
Interesting Schedule Planned for
Next Meeting.

The first meeting of the Social
Science Club, which was held
Friday, October 8, forecasts a successful, as well as a prosperous
year. In addition to the improvement in financial status, due to the
large number of new members,
marked enthusiasm was shown by
those who attended.
Three assistant secretaries were
elected in order to provide more
adequate methods for advertising
the meetings and public lectures.
Messrs. E. Smith, 'Junior • H. 0.
West,Sophomore, and W.14.Bruck,
Freshman, who were elected to fill
these positions, have always taken
an active interest in the Club.
A membership drive has been
planned, and a Membership Committee composed of one representative'
from each class, was appointed.
At the next meeting, to be held
on Friday, October 22, Mr. West
will read a paper on "The Platform of the Democratic Party,"
and Mr. Louis Kelley will discourse on "The Republican Platform." West is as ardent a
-Democrat" as Kelley is a "Republican," and undoubtedly those
in attendance will gain much
valuable information as to the
aims of both parties.
A discussion of the relative
merits of the two party platforms
will follow, and those versed in
the literature of the Presidential
campaign will be afforded an opportunity to display their knowledge.
A large attendance is hoped for.

A formal guard mount will be
held on Thursday afternoon at
4.30 on the upper quadrangle in
front of Gilman Hall. The guard
will be composed of picked cadets
from the Johns Hopkins R. 0.
T. C. Through the courtesy and
kindness of Lieut.-Col. George B.
Sharon, Commander of Camp
Holabird, an army band has been
provided.
This is the first of a series
of exhibition drills which are
planned by the R. 0. T. C., and
will be on a larger scale than anything of the like previously seen at
the University. The general public, as well as those interested in
the University, are cordially invited to be present.
